item.title: Solutions for the Crisis in Classical Music
item.description: Readers discuss ways to rescue the industry.

item.title: The Trad Life Fantasy Was Never Real
item.description: Stories from the past and present suggest that families have always needed a social safety net.

item.title: ICE Took Their Classmate. They Started Writing Letters.
item.description: Letters from students living in fear.

item.title: In Science We Trust. Or Do We?
item.description: Readers respond to a guest essay about the methods and reliability of science. Also: Opioid addiction; judges and presidents; cursive writing.

item.title: Slovenian Sphinx Flick Nixed!
item.description: Melania’s movie, not exactly boffo box office.

item.title: Pay More Attention to A.I.
item.description: A new world, hard to grasp and even harder to predict.

item.title: ‘Relieved,’ ‘Enthusiastic,’ ‘Nervous’: Three Economists React to Trump’s Fed Pick
item.description: Questions remain about the Fed’s independence, the future path of interest rates and whether Kevin Warsh can reform the institution as he has proposed.

item.title: Do We Want Live in Alex Pretti’s America or Gregory Bovino’s?
item.description: As in the Civil Rights battles of the 1960s, Americans are at a fork and must pick their path.

item.title: Trump Could Interfere With the Midterm Elections. Here’s How to Help.
item.description: The sanctity of the 2026 vote is indeed under threat.

item.title: Is the ICE Crackdown Finally Backfiring on Trump?
item.description: Amid national protests, the round table convenes to debate what anti-ICE tactics should look like.

item.title: Syria Must Protect Its Minorities
item.description: Without protection for the Kurds and other ethnic minorities, Syria will never be stable.

item.title: Dear ICE: Letters From Students Living in Fear
item.description: ICE took their classmate. They started writing letters.

item.title: Dear ICE: Letters From Students Living in Fear
item.description: ICE took their classmate. They started writing letters.

item.title: Is the ICE Crackdown Finally Backfiring on Trump?
item.description: Amid national protests, the round table convenes to debate what anti-ICE tactics should look like.

item.title: Próspera, Honduras and Trump’s Pardon of Hernandez
item.description: MAGA sees a borderless future in Honduras.

item.title: An Uncertain Future for Sundance and Indie Film
item.description: FOMO used to rule the Sundance Film Festival, but now it’s mostly fear.

item.title: The Border Patrol Is the Problem. It Always Has Been.
item.description: A Wild West frontier ethos has persisted to this day.

item.title: Kevin Warsh Is Trump’s Fed Pick. The Federal Debt Will Be the Real Boss.
item.description: The new boss of the Fed won’t be Trump’s nominee. It’ll be the federal debt.

item.title: Young People Are Using A.I. to Skip the Hardest Part of Growing Up
item.description: Artificial intelligence is replacing young people's social intuitions.

item.title: The Department of Homeland Security Was a Mistake From The Start
item.description: Since its founding in 2002, DHS has evolved into the unaccountable domestic security apparatus we have today, one that views the very people it is supposed to protect as threats not humans.

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace Is Anything But
item.description: America has conveniently forgotten that it once took the world to end conflicts.

item.title: A Farewell Column From David Brooks
item.description: After 22 wonderful years, I’ve decided to take the exciting and terrifying step of leaving in order to try to build something new.

item.title: This Week Has Revealed 3 Types of Americans
item.description: The clash in Minneapolis is asking us what kind of America we are.

item.title: Tucker Carlson’s Corrosive Bad Faith
item.description: To triumph in the modern Republican Party, you need to be able to wrench your soul into alignment with your ambition.

item.title: The Case for More Immigrants
item.description: The crackdown on immigrants is often sold as a benefit to citizens, but the columnist Jamelle Bouie argues it’s an economic self-injury and a moral failure.

item.title: The N.I.H. Director Thinks Covid Probably Started in a Lab
item.description: Scientists tried to prevent a pandemic. But did they open up Pandora’s box with their research? Dr. Jay Bhattacharya explains how he views the public health fallout to the Opinion columnist Ross Douthat.

item.title: How Trump Has Used the Presidency to Make at Least $1.4 Billion
item.description: The president took an oath to serve the American people. Instead, he’s focused his second term on enriching himself and his family, the Times editorial board argues.

item.title: The End of Nuclear Arms Control
item.description: Once the New START treaty ends, we will have returned to an era without limits, when arsenals can reach unconstrained heights.

item.title: Is America’s ‘Rupture’ China’s Moment?
item.description: The historian Adam Tooze discusses Davos, China and the fading of an old world order.

item.title: Senator Tina Smith: I Won’t Vote to Fund ICE Until It Gets Out of My State
item.description: Minnesotans have stood up for common decency and our founding principles.

item.title: Can Trust in Vaccines Be Built Through Skepticism?
item.description: Is the Trump administration reviving confidence in vaccination or destroying it? Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the director of the N.I.H., thinks an embrace of skepticism is key.

item.title: The Polls Are Clear. Americans Don’t Want This.
item.description: There is rising anxiety among Americans that the presence of an armed federal force in cities is actively making life less safe for people who live there.

item.title: Hind Rajab’s Mother: No Child Deserves to Die Like My Daughter
item.description: What was done to my daughter did not break me. It left me with a mother’s responsibility to ensure no child is left unheard.

item.title: A Plan to Restore Trust in Science From a ‘Fringe Epidemiologist’
item.description: Jay Bhattacharya, the N.I.H. director, says authorities broke the public’s trust in the Covid era. Now it’s up to outsiders to restore it.

item.title: Trump’s Lies Have a Purpose
item.description: Trump’s larger project is creating a parallel MAGA reality.

item.title: Philip Glass’s Protest at the Kennedy Center
item.description: Readers discuss Philip Glass’s refusal to allow the performance of his symphony at the Kennedy Center. Also: Real leaders at a time of crisis.

item.title: Can You Actually Fall in Love With a Chatbot?
item.description: A.I. relationships can’t replicate the complex, risky nature of love between two individuals, the psychotherapist Esther Perel argues on “The Opinions.”

item.title: A.I. Offers Comfort, Not Love
item.description: Is love without risk really love? On “The Opinions,” the psychotherapist Esther Perel argues that what makes relationships with A.I. appealing is exactly what makes them hollow.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Envoy: We Need ‘Total, Unfettered Access’
item.description: Trump’s special envoy to Greenland argues that the U.S. needs Greenland to defend it, American allies and American security.

item.title: Why Is My Son Being Left to Die on the Streets?
item.description: We thought America would keep him safe.

item.title: How to Bring Back the American Dream
item.description: Some of the best coaches we can find to help struggling children escape poverty may be other children and their families.

item.title: How to Come Together on Immigration
item.description: Readers respond to an essay by Representative Mike Lawler, Republican of New York. Also: A suggestion for Columbia’s new president; a “no” from Canada.

item.title: Kennedy Is Wrong to Make America Like Denmark on Vaccines
item.description: Vaccines are a social safety net, too.

item.title: The Havoc That One Disgruntled Student Can Wreak on a University
item.description: If college education is merely a transaction, educators — and facts — are vulnerable.
